pages:
Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 43194 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
June 2009 
 
 
 
 
Procurement Capacity Development for Project 
Implementation and Administration for 2009–2011 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  COSO  –  Central Operations Services Office 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  EA  –  executing agency 
  PIA  –  project implementation and administration 
  PIU  –  project implementation unit 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
Type  –  Regional—capacity  development  technical  assistance 
    (R-CDTA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Public sector management (economic and public affairs 
management) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Governance (public administration [national, decentralized, 
and regional], anticorruption), regional cooperation, capacity 
development  
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2 
Principal Director   H. Sharif, Central Operations Services Office (COSO) 
Directors  D. Yang, Central Operations Services Division 1, COSO 
  I. Santoso, Central Operations Services Division 2, COSO 
 
Team leader  T. Woods, Senior Procurement Specialist, COSO 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Project  implementation  and  administration  (PIA)  remains  a  challenge  for  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and its borrowers. Since 1978, ADB has funded PIA seminars with 
technical  assistance  (TA)  grants  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  borrowers  and  executing 
agencies (EAs) to manage projects. Senior and mid-level officials of EAs, central ministries, 
state  banks,  and  state  and  provincial  governments  from  34  developing  member  countries 
(DMCs)  have  participated  in  and  benefited  from  these  seminars,  which  have  centered  on 
policies and procedures for the procurement of goods, works, and consulting services, and for 
disbursement.  
 
2.  Seminars have so far been the medium of choice for procurement capacity development. 
There is now a need to (i) improve traditional seminar approaches and materials; (ii) design and 
deliver  short  courses  as  needed;  (iii) develop  and  introduce  new  e-learning  approaches; 
(iii) extend  procurement  capacity  development  beyond  the  training  programs  by  raising 
awareness of the importance of effective and efficient procurement systems in the project cycle, 
and developing and implementing supporting interventions; and (iv) introduce output monitoring 
systems. The foregoing measures are particularly important given the anticipated emphasis of 
many of ADB’s DMCs on the use of country procurement systems.  
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Country portfolio review missions and regular project supervision missions continue to 
observe delays in project implementation caused by EAs’ lack of understanding and familiarity 
with ADB’s procurement and disbursement policies and procedures. The high turnover of EA 
staff, typical of a project-based business environment, compounds the problem. A fundamental 
issue is the low importance accorded by DMCs to procurement. Procurement must take on a 
higher profile, and project implementation capacity must constantly improve. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  General 
 
4.  In this regional capacity development TA, not only will conventional PIA seminars in 
DMCs and regional seminars at ADB headquarters be held, as in the past, but short courses on 
specific procurement activities will also be prepared and delivered, as needed. Taking a broader 
view of procurement capacity development, the TA will help identify, design, and implement 
procurement interventions at different stages of the ADB project cycle that will improve the 
effectiveness and efficiency of projects. By introducing e-learning processes, the TA will also 
extend training to a wider audience, thereby making capacity development more sustainable. 
These initiatives will enable EAs to provide more integrated support throughout the project cycle 
from June 2009 to May 2011. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
B.  Impact and Outcome 
5.  The management of ADB’s project portfolio in its DMCs would improve. Staff in DMC 
EAs  and  project  implementation  units  (PIUs)  would  procure  goods,  works,  and  services

2   
(including consulting services) efficiently and at competitive prices, and according to ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). With the help of more varied 
training  approaches,  and  procurement  interventions  throughout  the  project  cycle,  project 
directors,  managers,  and  other  key  staff  members  of  EAs,  PIUs,  and  other  government 
counterpart agencies should develop the required proficiency in PIA. 
C.  Methodology and Key Activities 
  1.  Project Implementation and Administration Seminars 
 
6.  At least 18 PIA seminars will be conducted in the DMCs, and 1 PIA seminar at ADB 
headquarters and 1 PIA regional seminar will be held yearly.  
7.  The country seminars will have three basic components: recruitment of consultants, 
procurement of goods and civil works, and disbursement. The actual program in each country 
will depend on the needs of the EAs concerned. The seminars will be interactive and will 
integrate the use of online facilities with lectures, case studies, group discussions, workshops, 
and  practical  exercises.  They  will  normally  be  conducted  in  English,  with  translation  and 
interpretation facilities if needed. The seminars will deal mainly with the responsibilities of 
managers and other key project officials in project implementation, particularly during project 
start-up—procurement  management,  bidding,  and  project  design  and  monitoring  and  the 
attendant  critical  implementation  concerns  in  relation  to  ADB’s  results  framework.  Where 
appropriate, project management tools like the critical path method will be used; current PIA 
modules, particularly case studies, will be made more interactive and consistent with recent 
changes in ADB’s project processing and implementation procedures; and guest speakers from 
EAs, government and other procurement agencies, and project management entities will be 
invited to share their knowledge and experience.  
8.  The ADB headquarters and regional seminars will be similarly structured, but they will be 
concerned  mainly  with  procurement  policy  and  will  also  include  presentations  on  broader 
aspects  of  ADB  operations  for  new  project  directors  and  senior  policy  makers  of  central 
government agencies in the DMCs. 
  2.  Demand-Based Short Procurement Courses  
9.  Regional departments have asked ADB’s Central Operations Services Office (COSO) to 
deliver short courses for new EAs shortly after a project is approved. Therefore, besides the PIA 
seminars described in para. 7, shorter training courses will be designed and implemented as 
needed. The courses might be designed and implemented for a particular project or a particular 
procurement activity, e.g., reviewing bid documents, evaluating bids, evaluating proposals, or 
preparing terms of reference. 
  3.  E-Learning and E-Learning Modules 
10.  The development of e-learning tools, to spread awareness of procurement policies, 
procedures, issues, and allow wider use of the interactive exercises and case studies, will have 
priority. The e-learning applications will (i) complement the traditional approach to PIA seminars 
by increasing awareness and understanding of procurement policies and procedures even 
before the seminar, thereby freeing up seminar time for virtual interactive case studies and

3   
shortening the duration of the seminar overall; and (ii) extend the reach of specific procurement 
issues and activities. One e-learning tool would be a mandatory interactive introduction to ADB’s 
policies  and  procedures  for  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement.  Other 
e-learning  courses,  including  the  guided  preparation  of  procurement  risk  and  capacity 
assessments  and  procurement  plans,  would  be  based  on  demand.  ADB’s  experience  in 
developing e-learning approaches would also be helpful to public procurement and monitoring 
offices in the DMCs in developing their national e-learning programs. The e-learning portal 
would likewise soften the impact of the high turnover of staff in EAs by making it possible for 
new staff to learn online rather than wait for the next training course. All e-learning tools would 
be developed in English, Mandarin, Russian, Vietnamese, and other languages. 
D.  Monitoring Impact and Outcome 
11.  No structured monitoring of the impact or outcome of the PIA seminars has ever been 
undertaken. Output monitoring has been limited to usefulness to participants, based on their 
feedback after the seminars. Under this TA, the efficiency of procurement in general and, more 
specifically, the direct impact of the seminars on and their benefits to participants will also be 
evaluated through follow-up questionnaires distributed to participants in previous seminars. This 
increased emphasis on output monitoring is reflected in Appendix 1, which clearly shows the 
performance targets and indicators, verification sources, and assumptions and risks. 
E.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA of about $1,500,000 equivalent will support about 18 country PIA 
seminars, an annual PIA seminar at ADB headquarters, an annual regional PIA seminar, short 
procurement courses designed and delivered as needed, and pilot-testing and implementation 
of e-learning modules for procurement, consulting services, and disbursement. The detailed 
cost estimates are in Appendix 2. The TA will be financed with a grant from ADB’s TA funding 
program (TASF-IV). 
F.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The TA will begin in June 2009 and end in June 2011. COSO will be the EA and will be 
responsible for implementing (i) the PIA seminars, (ii) the demand-based short courses in 
procurement, (iii) the e-learning tools, and (iv) PIA output-based monitoring. 
 
14.  COSO will prioritize and prepare a PIA seminar program for each year during the TA 
period. Priority in program planning will be given to DMCs that (i) have assigned responsibility 
for loans approved in 2008 and 2009 to new EAs; (ii) are implementing large portfolios; (iii) have 
requested inclusion in the PIA program; and (iv) have been identified for support by ADB user 
departments, resident missions, or project review missions. Concerned government agencies 
and  ADB’s  regional  departments,  project  administration  unit  heads  network,  and  resident 
missions will be asked to nominate participants in the seminars. The resident missions will 
assist in coordinating logistic arrangements. Where appropriate, they will also guide COSO in 
deciding on program content and, in cooperation with government agencies, in determining the 
topics  that  need  to  be  emphasized  in  the  seminars.  COSO  will  hire  a  consulting  firm  or 
individual consultants to help update or upgrade the PIA training materials, and will implement 
the PIA seminar program in cooperation with ADB’s Controller’s Department, which will provide 
the facilitator for the disbursement component.

4   
15.  COSO will also coordinate the preparation and delivery of demand-based short-term 
procurement courses, and will hire either a consulting firm or individual consultants to help 
prepare and, if necessary and appropriate, deliver the courses.  
 
16.  From a review of the evaluation reports prepared by previous PIA seminar participants 
and  the  procurement  capacity  development  requirements,  key  topics  in  procurement, 
consulting, and disbursement will be selected for the e-learning exercises. COSO will hire a 
consulting firm or individual consultants to help design, pilot-test, and implement the e-learning 
modules. 
 
17.  All consultants will be hired according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). All disbursements under the TA will conform to ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.1 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for the Procurement Capacity Development for Project Implementation and Administration for 
2009–2011, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
1 ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook. Manila.

ADB = Asian Development Bank, BTOR = back-to-office report, CAR = Central Asian region, COSO = Central Operations 
Services Office, CPIA = country project implementation and administration, DMC = developing member country, EA = 
executing agency, PIU = project implementation unit, PMIS = portfolio management information system, RPIA = regional 
project implementation and administration, SSTA = small-scale technical assistance.

8  Appendix 3                     
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Country Project Implementation and Administration Seminars 
1.  Project Management and Procurement Specialists (international consulting 
firm or individual consultants; up to 6 person-months)  
1.  The objective of the input(s) is to prepare a case study for a large infrastructure project 
that demonstrates and integrates critical features of recruitment and procurement, appropriate 
for delivery to executing agency (EA) staff in a project implementation and administration (PIA) 
seminar, and to prepare the procurement modules for the e-learning courses to be designed, 
pilot-tested, and implemented by the e-learning specialists. 
 
(i)  Review and define, in cooperation with Asian Development Bank (ADB) Central 
Operations Services Office (COSO) staff, the critical elements of recruitment and 
procurement in the project cycle that can best be illustrated through a case study. 
 
(ii)  Review the information extracted and documented by COSO from an earlier 
roads project and, given the key procurement elements defined under (i) above, 
determine whether the information can be converted into a deliverable case 
study. 
 
(iii)  Write up the case study on the basis of the documented information. 
 
(iv)  Prepare a guide for case-study facillitators. 
 
(v)  Test the case study on COSO and ADB staff, and, if required, modify it to 
accommodate relevant feedback.  
 
(vi)  Design a monitoring system to retrieve feedback on the usefulness of the tool. 
 
(vii)  Train COSO staff in case-study preparation. 
 
(viii)  Prepare  a  final  report  summarizing  the  methodology  applied  and  providing 
recommendations for the future use of case studies. 
 
(ix)  In cooperation with COSO staff and after a review of feedback from previous PIA 
back-to-office  reports,  define  appropriate  topics  for  e-learning  modules  for 
consultant recruitment, goods and works procurement, and disbursement, to be 
designed, pilot-tested, and implemented. Prepare procurement modules for the 
e-learning courses. 
 
2.  Qualifications. The consulting firm or individual consultants will be project management 
and procurement advisers with experience in developing the capacity of project implementation 
units  (PIUs)  on  long-term  loan  projects,  preferably  funded  by  a  multilateral  organization. 
Familiarity with the ADB project cycle and project management training is essential.

Appendix 3  9 
B.  Demand-Based Short Procurement Courses 
1.  Procurement Capacity Development Specialist (international consulting firm 
or individual consultants; 2 person-months) 
3.  The objective of the input is to prepare, in response to demand from user departments, 
resident missions, and EAs or PIUs, two or three practical, hands-on courses on procurement 
topics critical to project implementation, with real-life examples or case studies, e.g., methods of 
preparing and reviewing bid documents, and evaluating bid documents for civil works and 
supply contracts (including information technology supply contracts). 
 
(i)  Review and analyze demand for short-term procurement training among user 
departments, resident missions, and EAs. 
 
(ii)  In cooperation with COSO staff, choose two or three critical topics for short 
procurement courses and identify suitable base materials from previous projects 
or from COSO’s procurement checklists to illustrate key issues. 
 
(iii)  Prepare training course materials with guidelines for the facilitator. 
 
(iv)  Pilot-test the courses with COSO staff and modify them on the basis of feedback 
from participants. 
 
(v)  Prepare an assessment tool for monitoring the impact of the training. 
 
4.  Qualifications. The consulting firm or individual consultants will have provided project 
management,  procurement,  and  contract  administration  advice  on  projects  funded  by 
multilateral  organizations,  or  will  have  worked  as  resident  engineers  and  assisted  in  the 
preparation  and  evaluation  of  bid  documents.  Involvement  in  procurement  capacity 
development, including procurement training, should be part of this experience. Familiarity with 
ADB’s project and procurement cycles is essential.  
C.  E-Learning Courses 
1.  E-Learning Specialist (international consulting firm or individual consultants; up 
to 6 person-months) 
5.  The  objective  of  the  input(s)  is  to  design,  pilot-test,  and  implement  at  least  three 
e-learning courses for recruitment, procurement, and disbursement. The disbursement course 
will  be  designed,  pilot-tested,  and  implemented  in  cooperation  with  ADB’s  Controller’s 
Department. 
 
(i)  In cooperation with COSO staff and after a review of feedback from previous PIA 
back-to-office  reports,  define  appropriate  topics  for  e-learning  modules  for 
consultant recruitment, goods and services procurement, and disbursement, to 
be designed, pilot-tested, and implemented. 
 
(ii)  Prepare the scripts for a new PIA e-learning system (e-PIA) with procurement, 
consulting services, and disbursement modules based on the existing PIA course

10  Appendix 3                     
content.  The  e-PIA  scripts  will  deal  with  participant  registration,  course 
administration, virtual presentations, short lectures, quizzes, tools, links (with 
ADB’s uniform resource locator), interactive activities (e.g., virtual case studies, 
illustrative  exercises),  course  evaluation,  provision  of  online  certificates,  and 
frequently asked questions. They should cover the PIA basics and provide links 
to relevant sites that provide information about recent COSO developments and 
changes. 
 
(iii)  With the scripts, design the modules using the most appropriate media, which will 
include, among others, video, virtual scrapbooks, photo albums, flash discs, and 
virtual document repositories. 
 
(iv)  Integrate  all  the  elements  into  a  fully  functional  and  open-source  content 
management system consistent with what is available in the chosen server. 
 
(v)  Advise on the selection of servers and assist in connecting the system to the 
server (either ADB or external), with due concern for the security of ADB’s virtual 
assets. 
 
(vi)  Train at least three site co-administrators to ensure the efficient and effective 
administration, supervision, and maintenance of the system content and site. 
 
(vii)  Provide support for the outreach program, site marketing, and analysis of system 
performance. 
 
6.  Qualifications. The consulting firm or individual consultants should be experienced in 
designing, applying, and managing e-learning methods including content management systems, 
presentations,  e-learning  scripts,  and  e-learning  systems.  A  background  in  engineering, 
business administration, or management (training and human resources development) would be 
appropriate. Depending on the media specified in the scripts, the candidates may subcontract 
some of the work to other media specialists as required.
